Young Europeans had the chance to speak directly with our Executive Board member Benoît Cœuré at our latest #ECBYouthDialogue in Milan. One of the topics they talked about was Europe’s ageing population https://t.co/6fRO2HaKkI

ECB announces start date for euro short-term rate (€STR) https://t.co/T7wO655oDW
Cœuré at #ECBYouthDialogue: Europe needs to pay more attention to those left behind – to those who need support in the face of a rapidly changing labour market.
Cœuré at #ECBYouthDialogue: Young students should receive the education they require to successfully compete in the global digital labour market.
Cœuré at #ECBYouthDialogue: Being part of the EU, the Single Market and the single currency is a strength. It contributes to creating jobs and offers young people opportunities to grow and develop.

Benoît Cœuré, Executive Board member of the ECB, speaks at today’s #ECBYouthDialogue @UniBocconi in Milan about what Europe can do for its young people. Read the full speech https://t.co/82YgnGiS0D https://t.co/odamNvbaaR

⚡️Missed today’s live Q&A with Chief Economist Peter Praet? Catch up here!

https://t.co/0ZR47pg5Hw
https://t.co/dgmGVxHUJ2
Minutes of the 27 February 2019 meeting of the working group on risk-free rates https://t.co/KbsERoS8Tc

This brings us to the end of our chat, and indeed of my last live Twitter Q&A from the ECB. Thank you for your questions. I tried to answer as many of them as possible and I really enjoyed the conversation. Peter Praet #AskECB https://t.co/d8WKnl599A
Praet: Let’s not get tied up here. A clear no to both questions #AskECB @jphlacour https://t.co/8kJKntVKZ9

Praet: No, they are a response to the downgrade of the economic outlook. Our latest decisions aim to maintain the accommodative policy stance necessary to reach our objective #AskECB https://t.co/p11YuB3939
Praet: Monetary policy remains effective but cannot be the only game in town #AskECB https://t.co/l9DAOzPOBf
Praet: I agree with you that you shouldn’t raise rates in the middle of a recession #AskECB https://t.co/39Er40G5vi
Letter Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Papadimoulis, MEP, on the ECB’s operational efficiency https://t.co/V3sCQsNm85 (EN) https://t.co/8SVcD7HqQG (EL)

Praet: Unfortunately I cannot answer your specific question. From a monetary policymaking perspective, even though there are pockets of very high prices, esp in cities, this cannot be addressed by monetary policy. It calls for local solutions – first and foremost macropru #AskECB https://t.co/arT4W7L3tG

Praet: We are confident that our current policy is appropriate to bring inflation back to our aim. At the last Governing Council meeting, we reiterated our determination to provide the monetary accommodation needed for a sustained convergence of inflation #AskECB https://t.co/dfAHDppFta
Praet: Collegiality. I would even say “l’esprit de camaraderie” – among my staff and fellow policy-makers. I will also miss the sense of humour of central bankers #AskECB https://t.co/HAXZswZvIr

Praet: The general idea that government debt can be financed by central banks is a dangerous proposition. In the past, this has resulted in hyperinflation and economic turmoil. That’s why central banks are independent @ramontremosa @pedroantoniak @Paolo_Guida @patrikakis #AskECB https://t.co/9LonoN2JqF

Praet: Our forward guidance is both: We say that we expect rates to remain at their present levels “at least through the end of 2019” (=Odyssean) and “in any case for as long as necessary” (=Delphic) #AskECB https://t.co/NjtmIAXD6W

Praet: It is up to governments, companies and households to take investment decisions. As a central bank, we can only influence the overall financing conditions of the economy #AskECB https://t.co/RYHb2nJy1e

Praet: I am afraid I don’t know your work but you have piqued my curiosity and I will check it out. My colleagues in communications would also love to know: who posts these great pictures of the ECB every day? #AskECB https://t.co/L0bfdg7okC

Praet: Yes, we trace the money bank by bank. Under TLTRO II only banks meeting a certain lending threshold get the most attractive conditions. Further details for TLTRO III will be communicated in due course #AskECB https://t.co/ngQmBXXonQ
Praet: As a central bank, we can create money to buy assets #AskECB https://t.co/zTQuU4y1ch
Praet: Private risk-sharing is key but cannot work without some degree of public risk-sharing #AskECB https://t.co/R7bYX9KU20
Praet: What you suggest would be monetary financing (= financing government spending with central bank money). It is prohibited and would destroy the trust in the euro #AskECB https://t.co/Fo84spFtzz

Praet: Our policies are necessary for sustained convergence of inflation towards below, but close to 2% over the medium term. So far the benefits of our policies have outweighed negative side effects #AskECB https://t.co/njbmvF9ISI
Praet: If we had had a specific month in mind, we wouldn’t have been shy about saying it #AskECB https://t.co/xJ9vp4vCzH

Praet: The euro has been a source of stability in a very turbulent environment. It is essential for the good functioning of the Single Market – the basis for our prosperity. That 75% of Europeans support the euro is telling #AskECB https://t.co/l4YsGqykdZ

Praet: I don’t think that a dual mandate would have changed our policies. All central banks, regardless of their specific mandates, are facing similar challenges and aim to maintain price stability #AskECB https://t.co/sdvIbgh5FM

Praet: It's not contagion, exactly. China is a major trading partner for us, so problems there will impact the demand for euro area goods and services, directly and indirectly #AskECB https://t.co/vs56RVheln

Praet: One is to better understand wage and price developments in the context of globalisation, the rising market power of some firms and digitalisation. Another one is the growing role of non-banks for monetary policy transmission #AskECB https://t.co/v2duYKF0b4

Praet: National central banks are key for the good functioning of our monetary union, which is composed of 19 countries. In fact, without the NCBs our job would be much more difficult #AskECB https://t.co/eHalo26y7d
Praet: Start thinking about what I am going to do #AskECB https://t.co/Z2K9AGQDx3
Praet: We are en route to reaching our inflation target. Getting there still requires the support of our monetary policy #AskECB https://t.co/XiyfMmno4g

Praet: No, negative rates continue to be a powerful tool to reach our price stability objective. The side effects are outweighed by the positive effects on financing conditions for firms and households #AskECB https://t.co/LncpUrURZy
Praet: The technology behind it looks promising for many industries. But bitcoin is not money #AskECB https://t.co/rsNGOXAKI2
Praet: I don't think so #AskECB https://t.co/rOIdhYJzfv

Praet: QE was very effective for the real economy. Lower interest rates have directly translated into lower bank lending rates for firms and households. This has meant more credit, more investment and more jobs (employment up by 10 million more since 2013) #AskECB https://t.co/fuhPAqTTXv
Pra€t: No #AskECB https://t.co/XizlTfEcOL

Praet: The Governing Council is a collegial body. My role is to present a thorough assessment of the economic situation and policy options. On that basis, we discuss and take our decisions #AskECB https://t.co/XHgJzFXOpB
Praet: Better understanding inflation dynamics, dealing with the lower bound and making policy within an incomplete monetary union #AskECB https://t.co/MKTkxYrbU3
Good afternoon, this is Peter Praet, Chief Economist at the ECB. I’m here for the next 45 minutes to answer your questions. Let’s get started, using #AskECB https://t.co/QweU3AD1tS
